headline: Single country offers depth; multi-country adds complexity
summary: For most first-time travelers, staying in one country provides a more coherent, less logistically complex experience. Multi-country trips make sense when combining genuinely different experiences (safari plus gorillas, for example). The added flights, border crossings, and logistics of multi-country trips rarely justify the complexity for wildlife viewing alone.

assumptions.text: Single-country trips have simpler logistics, fewer flights, and more coherent experiences.
Multi-country trips add value when combining genuinely different experiences.
Wildlife in adjacent East African countries overlaps significantly.

gains: Single: Simpler logistics and fewer flights
Single: Deeper exploration of one ecosystem
Multi: Gorillas plus traditional safari possible
losses: Single: Miss unique experiences in other countries
Single: May feel limited if time allows more
Multi: Complex logistics and more travel days
Multi: Less depth in each destination

change_conditions: If wanting gorillas plus traditional safari, multi-country is necessary.
If trip length is 10+ days, multi-country becomes more viable.
If this is a first safari, single country likely provides better experience.
If specific unique experiences require different countries, multi-country is justified.
